reviewText:
Had a lot of Fun when this Game was released.
The Community never was that big though.
And so it died out pretty quick, 2-3 Months after the release.
Because it has no Singleplayer Mode or even Bots, it is useless without other Players.

I don`t complain about the Game, the Game itself was very good.
But there are no Players anymore since about 1 Year now.

There have been numerous tries to revive the Game from the Community,
but to no avail.

Well, this happens a lot nowadays.
BUT, this Game is still beeing sold.
For full Price, even after it died out a long time ago.
And the Developer/Publisher knows about this.
They were involved in some of the efforts to revive this game.

In short: This Game is dead. The Developers and the Publisher are aware of this and they still sell it.
This is borderline Scam.
No... it is a Scam!

My Recommendation: Don't get this Game, not even when it is free!

reviewText: A philosophical exploration of our existence as portrayed through the extended metaphor of feline life. This is a stunningly poignant piece of modern film that addresses the human condition and the universal truths that we all come to know. The game (if we can consider it that, as its double meaning of game percieves our own viewpoint) Is quite frankly the most emotional pieces ever. The single player, astounding as it is see's the view of a cat who is afraid and runs away when faced with his own mortality, unsettling the viewer with both his unnatural body language and the underlying message- that there are no clear answers. 10/10

reviewText:
Special Force: Team X is made by Zombie Studios, the same guys who developed Blacklight: Tango Down and, its sequel, Blacklight: Retribuition. Unfortunatley, they made this average third-person squad-based multiplayer.

Being a team-based, it doesn't do a very good job at it since you don't have a specific role like in Battlefield. However, it wants you to work as a team with a multiplier count that increases if you're with your teamates. This game only has that incentive to work as a team and nothing else.

Regarding the shooting and gameplay, it's very standard, similar to Call of Duty. You progress unlocking weapons, attachments and special abilities. Special abilities include throwing a dog against your enemies, but that's the only fun you're gonna get out of those set of abilities.

Special Force: Team X innovates by dropping crazy weapons randomly on the map (like a chainsaw) and those maps are generated by the players. Before beginning a match, the map is seperated in 3 parts of which players vote which part and on which location on the map is placed.

Regarding the graphic quality, it's noting special but gets the job done easily. As to the animations, they're quite basic but also are tolerable.

Bottom line, don't get this game, the multiplayer scene is dead and it has not been updated with new content and I wasted 8 euros on it which could've been perfectly used on many other games. I was a bad consumer buying this game but I can compensate it by warning you not to buy it. I do not recommend at all.

reviewText:
*Disclaimer: I support this game and view it positively, but don't reccomend you buy it.  Read on for why.*
This game is one of those very depressing scenarios.
I bought it over two years ago when there were a few servers.  I haven't really played it since, so I started up the game.
There are no servers.  Not even a single server or single player.  Either way, let me move on to the actual game:
Special forces: Team X does something special, overall.  It takes an almost unbearably generic, cliche, basic formula for a multiplayer shooter and adds bits and bobs that turn it into something wonderful.
The game controls very smoothly, has reasonable controls, no bugs so to speak of, and overall works.
It is a generic multiplayer formula with two teams duking it out in deathmath, CTF, or outpost control (this last one may not exist I may be forgetting).  Players must murder each others' teams to win.
You create your class in a generic fashion, fixing together static primary and secondary weapons with little to no customization, choosing how you want your character to look.  You also get to choose your preferred grenade type, and preferred special attack (some are unique, such as spontaneously spawning individual attack dogs).
This generic formula for the game feels overall amazing.  The game is actually cover-based, which works quite well.  Shooting enemies feels EXTREMELY satisfying.  The guns all have a kick, and the flashy aesthetics are all enjoyable.  The graphics are cell-shaded, which works surprisingly well for this game, and it looks quite nice.
Where the game excels in is its one very, VERY unique feature.  No game up to this has ever used it, and to my knowledge, no current MFPS has ever used this idea:
Server lobby map selection is split into three parts.  There are several different maps
date: which each are split into three sections.  When players are voting for the map, there will be a winning map for component 1, component 2, and component 3.  Upon starting the game, the components will all be blended seamlessly into each other for the one map experience.\nHere's an example: Let's say I wanted chunk A) to be the a" component from 'scrapyard'
hoursPlayed: and chunk C) to be from 'construction yard.'  (Something really cool is that these are actually different maps; IE scrapyard" has B and C components as well) Each player then votes for each section.  My preferred chunk C)
voteText: "construction yard
helpfulPercent:
won the vote, but A and C ended up being completely different map components.  The enemy team might be swarming in from the offices, but I can still snipe them from the crane in construction yard! It's an AWESOME gimmick that I really wish was used more often.
The game is awesome in almost every way.  There isn't a lot of content at all, and won't entertain you for THAT long, but is generally an extremely fun, extremely high quality gaming experience.  But what is the giant whale in the bathtub? Why should you not buy it?  Well, you remember when I said that there is not a single player?  Well, of course, you must be able to spawn a solo server with bots, right?
...WRONG.  The game stupidly does not let you play with bots.  That means that the closest you will EVER get to actually playing, and enjoying this game, is by going into an empty server and playing around with the game mechanics all by yourself.  It's really quite depressing, this game could've been something really special, but the community being dead legitimately kills the game.
PROS:
>Game works flawlessly, perfect graphics, controls, no glitches to speak of
>Extremely fun gunplay
>Brilliant map customization factor
CONS:
>Not much depth, honestly while it could be worth the 10$, you don't necessarily feel like you are getting 10$ worth of content
>No ability to play with bots at all, despite lack of servers or online players

*I just made up the names of these maps.  I wasn't really paying attention to what they are called.

TL:DR;  Special forces: Team X takes a cliche, uninspired concept and through near-perfect design, fun and satisfying gameplay, and some unique map-based elements, makes it something truly special.  However, the lack of servers as well as bot functionality means that it is literally not possible to play the game.  Unless you consider blankly running around and shooting at a wall without any other players fun."
"

reviewText:
This was once one of my favorite cover based games...

Until my level got reset...

Then got reset again...

and again...

and again...

They finally fixed it or so they and we thought...

Then it happened again...

reviewText: This is an excellent game with all the core elements of a good, competitive, 3rd person shooter. You drop behind and hop over terrain easily, shootouts are fast paced and fun, and the voting on map layouts means you get something always familiar but with just enough variation to keep things interesting. That being said, it's nothing special. It won't revolutionize shooters or lend anything to future games. However, it strips away all the unnecessary elements and keeps everything fun and innovative about these kinds of games from the last several years. That makes for a solid game that's fun to play against others, even if it's almost entirely derivative.\n\nThe online community for this has somewhat died out, so I wouldn't recommend it too highly anymore; however, keeping an eye out for similar games from this publisher would not be unwise. A game like this without too high a pricetag that offers solid gameplay will always be worth the investment, in my opinion, even if it's a lot of rehashing. I can't in good conscience recommend the game anymore because the online community has sadly waned away.

reviewText: From the initial trailers, Special Forces: Team X showed some promise, but after spending some time with the game I find it hard to recommend it to people, especially with the problems it is faced with at the moment. There is nothing particularly wrong with the title itself, even if it is a little generic – you can still have some fun with it once you find a server with some others playing. What hurts it, though, is the unfinished polish, occasional bugs and lack of players, to the point where I believe Zombie Studios needs to rethink the future for Special Forces: Team X, because it will soon go the way of the dodo and be long forgotten within a month or so.

reviewText: I want to like this game. I should say, I'm a huge fan of 3rd Person Cover Shooters. Despite the game being poor, I was actually introduced to the cover shooter by Terminator Salvation for the 360. Then went on to play others like Gears of War, Deus Ex HR, and Ghost Recon Online. This game tries to fall somewhere inbetween the intense unforgiving tactical atmosphere of Ghost Recon Online while having a hard fast pace of Call of Duty and it doesn't really work. The art style is great, but numerous game breaking bugs, along with countless dead servers, lots of lag, unusual hit box miscalculations, and overpowered high tiered weapons make this a game to skip. I probably won't be playing anymore. If you want an online cover shooter, check out Ghost Recon Online!
